review_title: Not a place that respects individual differences

review_title: Good place to get your foot in the door in Higher Ed.
job_title: Admissions in River Forest, IL
pros: The work isn't that difficult once you learn it; beautiful campus; good location; low turnover (depending on the department); flexible work schedule; staff members are pretty involved in on campus events; strong staff council; great tuition reimbursement program
cons: Pay is not awful, but could be better; no salary increases for the past few years; many staff members have been there for years and never leave; many staff members are alumns so they do not bring a fresh perspective to the table; do not have enough student services for the demographic they serve (i.e. Hispanic students)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in River Forest, IL
pros:
Vacation will accrue fast.
Free Master's Degree if you want it.
Childcare on campus is nice.
Beautiful campus.
cons:
Deans are desperate and nervous. They don't know how to do their jobs.
They hire young "talent" to improve their struggles, but their new hire can't even conduct interviews properly.
Marketing is so lost... they don't know how to help our enrollment numbers... They complain about budget non-stop.
Our recruiters are awful....they don't hire people with personality to build rapport with our students....
This is FAR FROM a Catholic University.........their beliefs....and who they hire show it.... 
I've seen strong candidates for interviews come in and they are not picked.
This University is struggling in enrollment, and it shows....and they don't know what to do moving forward to fix this.... Go to another University like I did.
Don't work here.

review_title: Fantastic Student Jobs in the Academic Enrichment Center
job_title: Tutor in River Forest, IL
pros: Meaningful work, flexible hours, reasonable pay, positive work environment, friendly staff. Free to work on homework and personal projects when not handling student appointments.
cons: Not too many. This might be the perfect student job. However, training and professional development might be more effective if they took place in person (perhaps in staff meetings?) than they are with the current online method.

review_title: Being an Adjunct Professor is highly rewarding
job_title: Adjunct Professor in River Forest, IL
pros: The students are all good kids, and work hard with a positive attitude. The faculty are all friendly, and easily accessible. The facilities are new intermixed with the older, traditional buildings. The email system is highly functional, as is the website.
cons: The pay is relatively low, and of course, every college student worries a little too much about their grades. This, however, is the norm for most colleges in the country, and I would not say they are true cons.

review_title: You are taken advantage of by the low pay with increased responsibility.
job_title: Public Safety Patrol in River Forest, IL
pros: The student workers are nice to work with. Faculty and professors are nice to you and fun to interact with. It is a beautiful looking campus.
cons: Very low pay and only a maximum of 10 hours per week. Paycheck comes in once a month and would only come in to a total of $300 if you're lucky. Definitely not enough to for one to fend for themselves.

job_title: Teacher in Chicago, IL
pros: it was a small school, which was nice, everyone ( teachers, assistant teachers, student teachers) worked together. You could work and go to school.
cons: Pay is low,  upper management could have communicated better with staff.  For example director got rid of supplies that staff was using.

review_title: Dilbert cartoon in real life @ School of Education
job_title: Anonymous Employee in River Forest, IL
pros:
Gorgeous campus - the buildings are lovely and the landscape is well kept. 
Support - staff/faculty in positions of little/no power soldier on bravely, encouraging one another and actually doing the real work of taking care of students
cons:
The management at School of Education is arbitrarily brutal, rife with favoritism, and clueless about what needs to be done or how anything works. It reflexively assigns blame elsewhere for its own frequent mistakes and disorganization, and rarely recognizes the minor miracles performed on a regular basis by the faculty/staff of SOE.

The work environment at SOE is one of terrified silence. This is because the management metes out petty retribution to those who criticize, but even worse is the management's nasty bullying streak. If the management is good at one thing, it is picking out employees who will not fight back when singled out for arbitrary abuse, abuse that includes dismissal. 

If you do work here, make sure to document what you do and be ready to calmly but resolutely defend yourself.

Professors at SOE share work in vastly unequal amounts, depending on the individual professor's standing with the management; some professors work upward of 80 hrs/wk to the point of sickness and exhaustion; others are marginally productive and minimally present with little or no consequence.

The chaos at SOE suggests that the upper leadership of the University is either impotent or bafflingly clueless; why they have failed to intervene or even poll the SOE community about the notoriously awful work environment is a perennial subject of discussion among workers. HR is widely held to be filled with yes-men.

The university-wide data system is a hopeless mess, the Jenzebar system compromised by arbitrary and undocumented modifications. An IT employee commented - "If you get trained in Jenzebar, you'll still need months of training for the bizarre way DU uses it."

job_title: Graduate Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Friendly staff, the really care about your success when you graduate and how your position there will assist you in the future.
cons: Administrative roles are slow and difficult to work with. They have been there a while, and have very specific jobs. It is common to have a question for admin and be bounced around for a few days before somebody can/ will help.

review_title: The little engine that could of liberal arts colleges

cons: Administration can challenge your ideas and programming, while parents ay challenge your literature choices (based on their own personal beliefs) and not be good listeners.

review_title: I feel appreciated and that I am making an impact in the lives of students and alums; very rewarding.

review_title: They don't live according to their own Mission statement
